Conserving water has become increasingly important as Pennsylvania is currently in the midst of a statewide drought watch that began a week ago Paul Ruskin spokesman for the Office of the Physical Plant said PERIOD

Max Gill executive director of the State College Borough Water Authority said a drought occurring at this time of year is unusually early PERIOD

 Gill said PERIOD 

Gill said Pennsylvania is in only the preliminary stage of a drought watch which is more of a  to water companies and citizens to conserve water PERIOD

 Gill said PERIOD

Gill said there are many things students can do to conserve water PERIOD

 Gill said PERIOD 

Gill said full loads should be put in the washing machine PERIOD

Also when students brush their teeth the water should be turned off he said PERIOD

Ruskin said the state government through the Department of Environmental Protection declares what stage of a drought Pennsylvania is in at any given time PERIOD

He said the first stage a watch requires a  percent voluntary reduction of water use the second warning stage calls for a voluntary water usage reduction of  to  percent and the final stage is the  where you go into mandatory water reduction of  percent he said PERIOD

Ruskin said the mandatory stage is enforced by municipalities imposing fines on residents PERIOD In this stage Ruskin said various departments on campus follow certain regulations on water usage PERIOD

 he said PERIOD

Ruskin said droughts lead to brown lawns problems with campus landscaping and minimized water supplies PERIOD

He said Penn State has waterreducing showerheads along with restricting devices installed in water lines which help to reduce the amount of water used across campus PERIOD

 Ruskin said PERIOD

He said if students see any dripping faucets anywhere on campus they should call the physical plant offices service desk at  and report it PERIOD

Gill said the State College Borough Water Authority has been aggressive in cutting back on water usage adding that the borough has cut  gallons a day recently PERIOD  Gill said PERIOD

Ruskin said it would take more than one or two heavy rains to take the state out of a drought watch PERIOD
